topics.name: speed_velocity_acceleration
topics.explanation: Speed measures how fast an object is moving (distance/time). Velocity includes both speed and direction. Acceleration measures how quickly velocity changes. These are fundamental concepts in studying motion.
examples: A car travels 100 km in 2 hours. Its speed is 100/2 = 50 km/h.
If the car is moving at 50 km/h towards the north, its velocity is 50 km/h north.
If the car speeds up from 50 km/h to 80 km/h in 10 seconds, it has positive acceleration.
objectives: Understand the difference between distance and displacement

topics.name: equations_of_motion
topics.description: Mathematical relationships for uniformly accelerated motion
topics.explanation: The equations of motion relate the five kinematic variables: initial velocity (u), final velocity (v), acceleration (a), time (t), and displacement (s). These equations allow us to solve complex motion problems.
examples: A car starts from rest (u=0) and accelerates at 2 m/s² for 5 seconds. Final velocity: v = 0 + 2(5) = 10 m/s
objectives: Memorize the three equations of motion
Select appropriate equation for a given problem

topics.name: free_fall_projectile_motion
topics.explanation: Free fall is motion under the influence of gravity alone, with acceleration g = 9.8 m/s² downward. Projectile motion is motion under gravity with an initial horizontal velocity component.
examples: An object dropped from 100m height. Using s = ½gt², we find time = √(2×100/9.8) ≈ 4.5 seconds.
A ball thrown horizontally from a 50m building lands 100m away. We can calculate initial velocity and flight time.
For projectile motion: horizontal displacement = v₀ₓ × t, vertical displacement = ½gt²

topics.name: newton_first_law
topics.explanation: Newton's First Law states that an object at rest stays at rest, and an object in motion stays in motion unless acted upon by an external force. This is called inertia - the resistance of an object to change its state of motion.
examples: A book on a table stays there because no force is pushing it.
A car moving at constant velocity continues moving unless the brakes (external force) are applied.
In space with no gravity or friction, an object would move forever at constant velocity.

topics.name: newton_second_law
topics.explanation: Newton's Second Law relates force, mass, and acceleration: F = ma. A net force applied to an object causes acceleration proportional to the force and inversely proportional to the mass.
examples: A 2 kg object with 10 N force applied: a = F/m = 10/2 = 5 m/s²
Doubling the force doubles the acceleration.
Doubling the mass halves the acceleration.
Weight is the gravitational force: W = mg = 2 × 9.8 = 19.6 N
objectives: Apply F = ma to calculate force, mass, or acceleration
